This grant made possible consultation teams of experts to assist
new ETV stations, or stations in final planning stages, which requested
this service. It provided funds for both expenses and consultation fees
for such visits. New stations, or associations and institutions with con¬
struction permits for new stations, submitted detailed requests to the NAEB
for consultants, specifying the areas, such as engineering, program plan¬
ning, administration, production, etc., in which assistance was needed.
The NAEB then contracted with the best consultants available to spend from
one day to a week at the new station. Although started purely on an ex¬
perimental basis, because the NAEB did not know whether such a project
would prove practical, the consultation service proved so helpful that the
two grants from the Ford Foundation, in 1956 and 1957, provided further
funds for this purpose, as mentioned above.
A list of the visits made by individual consultants and consultation
as a result of this service may be found in Appendix 6.
In all instances, the administration of the stations, associations
and institutions visited reported that the consultation service had been of
vital importance in providing them with the knowledge and assistance needed
to bring about successful operation (and in some cases installation) of their
stations. In some instances, it was stated that plans to put an ETV station
on the air would have been dropped or abandoned without the help of the
consultation service. For example. Dr, Jere Chase, Director of Develop¬
